author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Welcome @ingydotnet! 

The package doesn’t seem to have any content yet, so it’s not ready for registration. See https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General#should-i-register-my-package for some related points. We welcome you to resubmit the package once it has some functionality implemented.

@ericphanson I have some questions...

For background I am planning to implement the YAMLScript language on top of lots of languages including Julia.

The working prototype is in Perl on CPAN now: https://metacpan.org/pod/YAMLScript

And the mono repo is https://github.com/yaml/yamlscript

I am learning how to publish in lots of languages right now.

Reading of Julia publishing it wanted my repo name to be YAMLScript.jl but I'd prefer it to live in https://github.com/yaml/yamlscript/tree/main/julia
Is that possible? If so what should I do?

Also how much of YS do you want me to implement in Julia before registering it?
@ericphanson I'll start adding some content while I wait for a reply...

> Reading of Julia publishing it wanted my repo name to be YAMLScript.jl but I'd prefer it to live in https://github.com/yaml/yamlscript/tree/main/julia
> Is that possible? If so what should I do?

Yep! Specify the directory https://juliahub.com/ui/Registrator. That directory will need a copy of the license.

> Also how much of YS do you want me to implement in Julia before registering it?

It is supposed to be code that is ready for others to use, like a first release. Generally we just look to see it does “something” and isn’t a purely “personal” package (although we don’t have time to look at all registrations so the process is kinda random unfortunately).
ok, I'll put some work into it. thanks

body:

title: New package: YAMLScript v0.0.16
